qa_pairs.question: Where is Shayla Putnam originally from and how long has she been in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Shayla Putnam is originally from Idaho and moved to San Francisco about four years ago.
qa_pairs.source_text: um my name is Shayla um I am actually from Idaho and I moved here about five years ago um to the bay and then I moved to San Francisco about four years ago

qa_pairs.question: What subject does Shayla Putnam teach and where?
qa_pairs.answer: Shayla Putnam teaches ceramics at George Washington High School.
qa_pairs.source_text: Im currently a our educator I teach ceramics at George Washington High

qa_pairs.question: What was Shayla's first apartment experience like in college?
qa_pairs.answer: Shayla's first apartment was a one-bedroom that she rented for $650 a month, which included parking and lots of space.
qa_pairs.source_text: my first apartment that I owned it was a one bedroom apartment and I paid 650 a month for that and it was a decent apartment it was it was livable it was great parking included lots of space

qa_pairs.question: Why did Shayla move to the Bay Area?
qa_pairs.answer: Shayla moved to the Bay Area to support a job as a regional manager in retail and to intern with a sculptor, which eventually led to her teaching ceramics.
qa_pairs.source_text: I spontaneously moved out to the bay to help support that job and was a regional manager for a while during that time it was retail oriented and I didnt want to let go of my my Arts intentions so I started interning with a incredible sculptor an artist named John Toki in Richmond

qa_pairs.question: What challenges has Shayla faced with housing in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Shayla has moved every year due to various reasons like taking advantage of pandemic prices or lease issues, and she finds it difficult to afford living in San Francisco without a partner.
qa_pairs.source_text: here in San Francisco though has been quite the journey Im Ive moved every single year that Ive lived here for various reasons whether its taking advantage of the pandemic prices or noticing something in my lease was a little less than legal uh and its just yeah um we live in the sunset right now me and my partner and honestly if I didnt have a partner I wouldnt I dont think I would have been able to afford to live out here as easily as I have

qa_pairs.question: What was Shayla's experience with her landlord in the Mission?
qa_pairs.answer: Shayla had a sketchy landlord situation in the Mission where the lease stated tenants would be liable for all apartment issues, prompting her to move.
qa_pairs.source_text: but that was the apartment that had the sketchy landlord situation um in the lease somewhere they had written that basically if anything were to go wrong in the apartment that was our fall and that wed be liable for it like including Plumbing

qa_pairs.question: How does Shayla view the impact of housing accessibility on youth independence?
qa_pairs.answer: Shayla believes that lack of affordable housing makes it hard for youth in the city to be independent and live on their own, as many rely on their parents for housing and college expenses.
qa_pairs.source_text: I think having um plus access to affordable housing and housing in general makes it really hard for um the youth in the city to be able to be more independent right away and be able to live on their own or with roommates

qa_pairs.question: What is Shayla's perspective on the availability of housing in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Shayla feels there is a lot of empty housing in San Francisco that is not affordable, which is a significant issue.
qa_pairs.source_text: I feel like the thing that gets me is that there is so much housing available thats empty and just not affordable that makes it such an issue

qa_pairs.question: What does Shayla believe would be the benefits of making housing more accessible?
qa_pairs.answer: Shayla believes that making housing more accessible would allow more native residents to stay, become teachers, and contribute to the city, improving retention and community development.
qa_pairs.source_text: if we have accessible housing youre going to be able to have more native residents going to be able to become teachers going to be able to stay in the city rather than having to go elsewhere

qa_pairs.question: How does Shayla view the impact of living conditions on quality of life?
qa_pairs.answer: Shayla believes that living conditions, such as overcrowding in small apartments, negatively impact quality of life and that people should have choices in where they live.
qa_pairs.source_text: I have lived in places where families have like six people in a one-bedroom apartment as a neighbor um and I dont think a lot of people will actually choose that as their life because its not really a place where you have space to live and grow and develop

qa_pairs.question: What are Shayla's thoughts on housing development in different parts of San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Shayla thinks adding housing in the Mission is counterintuitive due to its density, and suggests more development in suburban areas like the Sunset to improve accessibility and transportation.
qa_pairs.source_text: adding housing into the mission and and already extremely densely populated side of the city seems counterintuitive to me
